organization_owner: and ongoing suitability assessment. Process ensures reliable personnel; documented and retained per GLBA requirements.
version: Per GLBA Safeguards Rule Element 2 (16 CFR 314.4(b)(1)) and Privacy Rule (12 CFR 1016.3), institutions must implement administrative safeguards including personnel and security management. Background checks are component of personnel security; required for all employees with access to customer information; must be appropriate to risk level of position. Background check components: employment history verification; education verification; credit check; criminal history check; professional reference checks; driving record (if relevant); drug screening (at institution discretion). Background check standards: FCRA compliance; Fair Credit Reporting Act governs background check procedures; institution must obtain written consent from applicant; adverse action procedures if unfavorable information; right to dispute; confidentiality of results. Timing: background checks completed before hiring; conditional offer contingent on results; results documented and retained; periodic re-screening may be required. Applicant consent: candidate informed of background check; consent obtained prior to screening; applicant advised of rights; negative information handling.

column13: Background Check Components: Employment Verification: verify prior employment history; confirm dates of employment; confirm job titles and responsibilities; confirm reason for separation; check for unexplained gaps; contact prior employers if possible; verify accuracy of resume. Education Verification: confirm degrees claimed; verify graduation dates; confirm major/concentration if stated; verify honors/awards; contact educational institutions directly; red flags: diploma mills, unaccredited institutions, false credentials. Credit Check: review credit report; assess financial responsibility; look for patterns: late payments, defaults, high debt levels, bankruptcy history; negative credit may indicate higher fraud risk; more stringent for positions with financial access; Fair Credit Reporting Act compliance required. Criminal History Check: review criminal record databases; assess nature and severity of offenses; assess time since offense; assess relevance to position; embezzlement, fraud, dishonesty crimes particularly concerning for financial institution positions; violent crime assessment for positions with customer contact; any false statements on application concerning. Professional References: contact references provided by candidate; verify current role and information; assess performance, reliability, honesty, integrity; ask about reason for leaving; identify concerns or red flags; document calls. Driving Record: check if position involves driving; assess driving history; violations, accidents, suspensions concerning; relevant to positions requiring travel or transport of materials. Drug Screening: institution discretion; typically for safety-sensitive positions; may use urinalysis, hair test, or other methods; conducted by licensed facility; proper chain of custody; results confirmed. Other Considerations: Social Security number verification; address history verification; litigation history (civil suits); regulatory enforcement actions; sex offender registry check if appropriate. Risk-Based Approach: background check depth depends on position risk; higher-risk positions (IT staff, compliance, audit, lending): comprehensive background check; lower-risk positions: simplified check; customer-facing positions: moderate depth; system access positions: thorough check. Background Check Provider: use reputable third-party provider; ensure FCRA compliance; understand their processes; ensure data security of applicant information; verify accuracy of results; understand adverse action procedures. Applicant Rights (FCRA): pre-disclosure notice: applicant must be informed background check will be conducted; authorization: written consent required before check; adverse action notice: if negative information found, applicant must be notified; opportunity to dispute: applicant may dispute inaccuracy; final notice: if hiring decision based on background check. Timing and Deadlines: background checks completed expeditiously; job offer typically conditional on favorable results; results obtained before hire date; offer letter states conditional nature. Documentation: maintain in personnel file; retain indefinitely or per policy; secure storage; access limited to HR and managers; results confidential; protected information. Ongoing Suitability Assessment: periodic re-screening may be required; particularly for high-risk positions (security, audit, compliance); monitoring of criminal activity; monitoring of regulatory actions; assessment if position changes to higher-risk role. New Hire Adverse Action: if results negative; provide pre-adverse action notice; allow applicant time to respond; provide final notice if decision made to reject; document all decisions; maintain records of applicant response. Current Employee Issues: if during employment employee arrested or convicted; assess relevance to position; assess impact on customer trust; may require disciplinary action; may require role change; may require termination; assess customers affected if sensitive position; regulatory notification if required. Regulatory Examination: examiners assess background screening program; review sample of hired employees; verify background checks completed; assess criteria used; ensure FCRA compliance; evaluate adverse action procedures; assess documentation completeness. Common Examination Findings: no documented background check for some employees; inadequate screening procedures; FCRA non-compliance; lack of adverse action notice; no documentation retention; inadequate re-screening; inadequate risk assessment for position type.

definition: Written agreements requiring employees to maintain customer information confidentiality. Includes non-disclosure agreements (NDAs) and confidentiality policies covering obligations
version: Per GLBA Privacy Rule (12 CFR 1016.3) and Safeguards Rule, institutions must maintain administrative safeguards including policies and procedures for personnel security. Confidentiality agreements are administrative control establishing employee obligations. Agreements establish: obligation to keep customer information confidential; understanding of prohibited disclosures; acknowledgment of legal requirements; understanding of consequences; post-employment obligations. Confidentiality agreement signed by all employees with customer information access; prior to access granted; required as condition of employment; breach results in termination or legal action. Content: general confidentiality obligation; specific prohibition of customer information disclosure; prohibition of unauthorized copying; limitation of access to need-to-know; secure handling procedures; prohibition of removal from premises; password protection; encryption use; incident reporting; violation consequences; continuing obligation post-employment; understanding of legal framework.

key_features: Human Resources for coordination; Legal counsel for agreement drafting and enforcement; Compliance for policy oversight; Managers for employee acknowledgment and monitoring

column13: Confidentiality Agreement Components: Confidentiality Obligation: employee acknowledges customer information is confidential; agrees to maintain confidentiality during and after employment; understands legal basis for confidentiality (GLBA, banking regulations, privacy laws); agrees not to disclose without proper authorization. Scope of Information: definition of confidential information (customer NPI, account information, transaction history, credit information, health information, other sensitive data); applies to information in any form (physical, electronic, verbal). Permitted Uses: employee may use confidential information only for specified business purposes; only for functions of employee's position; no use for personal benefit; no use for competitor's benefit; no commercial use. Permitted Disclosures: only to other authorized employees on need-to-know basis; only to regulators upon legal request; only with written authorization; disclosure to law enforcement if required by law. Prohibited Conduct: no copying without authorization; no removal from premises; no sharing on social media; no discussion in public areas; no discussion with family or friends; no unauthorized access; no disclosure to vendors or service providers without agreement; no retention of information after employment ends. Secure Handling: appropriate use of passwords; multi-factor authentication; encryption of sensitive data; no sharing of login credentials; no leaving documents unattended; no disposal in regular trash; secure disposal procedures; clean desk policy; privacy screens; phone security. Incident Reporting: obligation to report any suspected breach or unauthorized access; report suspicious activity; report lost or stolen documents; report phishing attempts; report system compromise; timely reporting required; non-retaliation assurance. Duration of Obligation: confidentiality obligation continues after employment ends; indefinite duration unless specified otherwise; survival clause survives termination; obligation extends to family members and associates of employee if information shared. Consequences of Breach: breach results in disciplinary action; may result in termination; may result in legal action; damages for breach; injunctive relief; exclusion from industry positions; criminal prosecution if theft; reference during future employment inquiries. Post-Employment Requirements: return all confidential information upon separation; delete from personal devices; no access to systems after termination; no contact with customers without authorization; no use of customer lists; no disparagement of customer information handling; cooperation in transition; final certification of information return. Understanding of Legal Framework: employee understands GLBA confidentiality requirements; understands federal and state privacy laws; understands bank secrecy act obligations; understands potential criminal liability for disclosure; understands civil liability; understanding demonstrated through signature. Acknowledgment and Signature: employee acknowledges reading and understanding agreement; agrees to comply with all terms; authorization of background check if relevant; signature of employee; date of signing; signature of manager or HR witness; maintained in personnel file. Annual Renewal: confidentiality agreement renewed annually or when role changes; acknowledgment of continued obligations; update of policy changes; reminder of consequences. Policy Distribution: confidentiality policy provided to all employees; included in employee handbook; available on company intranet; training on requirements; acknowledgment of receipt; updated policy distribution when changes made. Regulatory Alignment: institution specific policies implementing GLBA requirements; aligned with other institution policies; consistent with examination expectations; reflected in employment agreements; understood as condition of employment. Termination Procedures: upon employment termination, confidentiality obligation emphasized; return of company equipment with customer information; deletion of information from devices; no post-employment contact with customers; warning of legal consequences for unauthorized disclosure; exit interview conducted. Enforcement: investigation of alleged breaches; interview of involved employee; assessment of damage; termination if breach substantiated; legal action if criminal conduct or significant damage; civil suit for damages; injunctive relief if ongoing threat. Examination Focus: examiners assess confidentiality agreements; review sample of signed agreements; assess agreement adequacy; assess communication of obligations; assess enforcement of violations; assess consequences for breaches.

definition: Procedures for employee termination or role change to ensure customer information is returned
applicable_to: and confidentiality is maintained. Includes exit interviews
status: and final verification of information return.
key_features: Per GLBA Safeguards Rule Element 2 (16 CFR 314.4(b)) and Privacy Rule, institutions must manage personnel transitions to maintain information security and confidentiality. Employee separation procedures are critical control; must occur for all separating employees; must verify information return; must revoke access; must maintain confidentiality obligations. Separation procedures: advance notification to compliance and IT; system access audit; data return documentation; exit interview; confidentiality reminder; system access revocation; device return; final verification. Timing: procedures begin upon notice of separation; completed on or before last day of employment; final access revoked as final act; access credentials destroyed. Documentation: maintained in personnel file; signed by employee if possible; signed by manager; IT confirmation of access removal; completion certification.
column11: All separating employees; all role changes to lower-access positions; applies to all institution sizes; includes resignations, terminations, retirements, transfers; contractors and temporary staff
column12: Human Resources for coordination; IT Security for system access management; Compliance for procedure oversight; Manager for employee separation; Legal for documentation. Facilities for badge/access device collection.
column13: GLBA Safeguards Rule Element 2 (16 CFR 314.4(b)) personnel security; Privacy Rule administrative safeguards; Examination expectations for separation procedures; Regulatory guidance on information security during transitions

column15: Employee Separation Process: Notification Phase: employee gives notice or termination notice given; HR documents separation date; compliance notified of separation; manager notified; IT notified; separation flag set in HR system. Pre-Separation Activities: access audit to identify systems employee uses; identification of information employee has access to; planning for transition of responsibilities; arrangement for knowledge transfer; identification of confidential information employee may have. Final Week Activities: system access review; verification of customer information return; identification of company devices with access; audit of home office (if applicable); review of email for customer information; backup or archive of work files; review of shared drives. Exit Interview: conducted by HR or Compliance; reminder of confidentiality obligations; continuation of obligations post-separation; instruction to return all information; instruction to delete information from personal devices; instruction regarding legal consequences; no unauthorized contact with customers; no unauthorized use of customer information; signature confirming understanding. Equipment Return: employee returns laptop and desktop (if applicable); returns mobile devices; returns access badges; returns keys; returns any physical documents containing customer information; receipt documented; employee signs equipment return form. System Access Removal: IT revokes access to all systems; email access removed; VPN access removed; system access removed; password reset if shared credentials; multi-factor authentication devices returned; access verified to be removed; system access removal ticket closed. Email and Data Review: IT reviews email for customer information before deletion; customer information archived if needed; email archived per retention policy; deletion verified; shared drives reviewed; employee files reviewed; backup of files required if needed. Information Return Certification: employee certifies all customer information returned; employee certifies no copies retained; employee certifies personal devices cleared of customer information; employee certifies no printouts retained; certification signed; if employee unavailable, manager signs on behalf. Final Day Procedures: final access removal; badge/access card deactivated; phone deactivation; facility access removal; parking lot access removal; escorted exit if necessary; final security checkpoint. Post-Separation Activities: legal notice regarding ongoing obligations; copy of confidentiality agreement provided as reminder; final paycheck issued; COBRA notification if applicable; references policy communicated. Legal Follow-Up: if breach suspected, legal review; potential demand letter; monitoring of social media; monitoring of competitor positions. Regulatory Notification: if employee had access to significant information and circumstances suggest risk, may require notification to regulators. Documentation: maintain personnel file with: separation notice; confidentiality reminder; equipment return documentation; IT confirmation of access removal; exit interview notes; information return certification; final verification checklist. Contractor Separation: contractors treated similarly; equipment return; access removal; confidentiality reminder; information return; may require final certification from contractor organization. Internal Transfer (Role Change): if employee transfers to role with lower access; similar procedures applied; access to previous systems removed; access to new systems established; training on new role's confidentiality requirements; audit of previous access. Examination Focus: examiners assess separation procedures; review sample of separations; verify access removal; verify equipment return; assess exit interview documentation; verify confidentiality reminder; assess information return verification; assess timely completion.
